00010 #ifndef _STACK_CONTAINER_H___
00011 #define _STACK_CONTAINER_H___
00012 
00013 #include <memory>
00014

00040 template<class T, size_t stack_capacity>
00041 class stack_allocator : public std::allocator<T>
00042 {
00043 public:
00044         typedef typename std::allocator<T>::pointer pointer;
00045         typedef typename std::allocator<T>::size_type size_type;
00046 
00047         // Backing store for the allocator. The container owner is responsible for
00048         // maintaining this for as long as any containers using this allocator are
00049         // live.
00050         struct Source
00051         {
00052                 Source() : m_isStackBufferUsed(false)
00053                 { }
00054 
00055                 // Casts the buffer in its right type.
00056                 T* stack_buffer()
00057                 {
00058                         return reinterpret_cast<T*>(m_stackBuffer);
00059                 }
00060 
00061                 const T* stack_buffer() const
00062                 {
00063                         return reinterpret_cast<const T*>(m_stackBuffer);
00064                 }
00065 
00066 
00067                 //
00068                 // IMPORTANT: Take care to ensure that stack_buffer_ is aligned
00069                 // since it is used to mimic an array of T.
00070                 // Be careful while declaring any unaligned types (like bool)
00071                 // before m_stackBuffer.
00072                 //
00073 
00074                 // The buffer itself. It is not of type T because we don't want the
00075                 // constructors and destructors to be automatically called. Define a POD
00076                 // buffer of the right size instead.
00077                 char m_stackBuffer[sizeof(T[stack_capacity])];
00078 
00079                 // Set when the stack buffer is used for an allocation. We do not track
00080                 // how much of the buffer is used, only that somebody is using it.
00081                 bool m_isStackBufferUsed;
00082         };
00083 
00084 
00085         // Used by containers when they want to refer to an allocator of type U.
00086         template<class U>
00087         struct rebind
00088         {
00089                 typedef stack_allocator<U, stack_capacity> other;
00090         };
00091 
00092 
00093         // For the straight up copy c-tor, we can share storage.
00094         stack_allocator(const stack_allocator<T, stack_capacity>& rhs)
00095                 : std::allocator<T>(), m_source(rhs.m_source)
00096         { }
00097 
00098         // ISO C++ requires the following constructor to be defined,
00099         // and std::vector in VC++2008SP1 Release fails with an error
00100         // in the class _Container_base_aux_alloc_real (from <xutility>)
00101         // if the constructor does not exist.
00102         // For this constructor, we cannot share storage; there's
00103         // no guarantee that the Source buffer of Ts is large enough
00104         // for Us.
00105         // TODO: If we were fancy pants, perhaps we could share storage
00106         // iff sizeof(T) == sizeof(U).
00107         template<class U, size_t other_capacity>
00108         stack_allocator(const stack_allocator<U, other_capacity>& other)
00109                 : m_source(NULL)
00110         { }
00111 
00112         // Empty ctor to fix build bug in GCC
00113         stack_allocator() 
00114                 : m_source(NULL)
00115         { }
00116 
00117         // Main ctor
00118         explicit stack_allocator(Source* source) : m_source(source)
00119         { }
00120 
00121 
00122         // Actually do the allocation. Use the stack buffer if nobody has used it yet
00123         // and the size requested fits. Otherwise, fall through to the standard allocator.
00124         pointer allocate(size_type n, void* hint = 0)
00125         {
00126                 if (m_source != NULL && !m_source->m_isStackBufferUsed
00127                         && n <= stack_capacity) {
00128                                 m_source->m_isStackBufferUsed = true;
00129                                 return m_source->stack_buffer();
00130                 }
00131                 else
00132                 {
00133                         return std::allocator<T>::allocate(n, hint);
00134                 }
00135         }
00136 
00137         // Free: when trying to free the stack buffer, just mark it as free. For
00138         // non-stack-buffer pointers, just fall though to the standard allocator.
00139         void deallocate(pointer p, size_type n)
00140         {
00141                 if (m_source != NULL && p == m_source->stack_buffer())
00142                         m_source->m_isStackBufferUsed = false;
00143                 else
00144                         std::allocator<T>::deallocate(p, n);
00145         }
00146 
00147         // Is true, if allocator currently uses stack
00148         bool isOnStack() const
00149         {
00150                 if(m_source == NULL)
00151                         return false;
00152 
00153                 return m_source->m_isStackBufferUsed;
00154         }
00155 
00156 private:
00157         Source* m_source;
00158 };
00159 
00161 
00163 
00175 template<typename TContainerType, size_t stack_capacity>
00176 class stack_container
00177 {
00178 public:
00179         typedef TContainerType ContainerType;
00180         typedef typename ContainerType::value_type ContainedType;
00181         typedef stack_allocator<ContainedType, stack_capacity> Allocator;
00182 
00183         // Allocator must be constructed before the container!
00184         stack_container() : m_allocator(&m_stackSource), m_container(m_allocator)
00185         {
00186                 // Make the container use the stack allocation by reserving our buffer size
00187                 // before doing anything else.
00188                 m_container.reserve(stack_capacity);
00189         }
00190 
00191         // Getters for the actual container.
00192         //
00193         // Danger: any copies of this made using the copy constructor must have
00194         // shorter lifetimes than the source. The copy will share the same allocator
00195         // and therefore the same stack buffer as the original. Use std::copy to
00196         // copy into a "real" container for longer-lived objects.
00197         ContainerType& container() { return m_container; }
00198         const ContainerType& container() const { return m_container; }
00199 
00200         // Is true, if container is currently on stack
00201         bool isOnStack() const
00202         {
00203                 return m_allocator.isOnStack();
00204         }
00205 
00206         // Support operator-> to get to the container. This allows nicer syntax like:
00207         //   StackContainer<...> foo;
00208         //   std::sort(foo->begin(), foo->end());
00209         ContainerType* operator->() { return &m_container; }
00210         const ContainerType* operator->() const { return &m_container; }
00211         ContainerType& operator*() { return m_container; }
00212         const ContainerType& operator*() const { return m_container; }
00213 
00214 protected:
00215         // Allocator must be constructed before the container!
00216         stack_container(size_t resrved_capacity) : m_allocator(&m_stackSource), m_container(m_allocator)
00217         {
00218                 // Make the container use the stack allocation by reserving our buffer size
00219                 // before doing anything else.
00220                 m_container.reserve(resrved_capacity);
00221         }
00222 
00223         typename Allocator::Source m_stackSource;
00224         Allocator m_allocator;
00225         ContainerType m_container;
00226 
00227 private:
00229         stack_container(const stack_container&);
00230         const stack_container& operator=(const stack_container&);
00231 };
00232 
00234 
00236 
00247 template<class TContainerType, size_t stack_capacity, size_t reserved_capacity>
00248 class stack_string_container : public stack_container<TContainerType, stack_capacity>
00249 {
00250 public:
00251         // Allocator must be constructed before the container!
00252         stack_string_container() : stack_container<TContainerType, stack_capacity>(reserved_capacity)
00253         {
00254         }
00255 
00256 private:
00257         // disallow copy ctor and operator=
00258         stack_string_container(const stack_string_container&);
00259         const stack_string_container& operator=(const stack_string_container&);
00260 };
